intro: Turnera simulans, commonly known as the yellow wood sorrel, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States and parts of Mexico. It is a low-growing perennial shrub that typically reaches heights of 1 to 2 feet. The plant features heart-shaped leaves with a distinctive waxy coating and produces clusters of yellow flowers that bloom in the spring. Its flowers are composed of five petals and are often visited by pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Turnera simulans is adapted to thrive in woodland and shaded environments, often found in moist, well-drained soils.
